metadata.description: Class 9 Science - Chapter 9: Force and Laws of Motion

question.text: (CBSE 2023) Newton's first law of motion is also called:
question.explanation: First law: body remains at rest/uniform motion unless acted upon by external force. Defines inertia.

question.text: (SEBA 2023) The SI unit of force is:
question.explanation: Force SI unit: Newton (N). 1 N = 1 kg·m/s². Named after Sir Isaac Newton.

question.text: (CBSE 2022) Which law explains why a gun recoils when fired?
question.explanation: Third law: action (bullet forward) = reaction (gun backward). Momentum conservation: m₁v₁ = m₂v₂.

question.text: (SEBA 2022) The product of mass and velocity is called:
question.explanation: Momentum (p) = m × v. Vector quantity, SI unit: kg·m/s. Conservation of momentum in isolated system.

question.text: (CBSE 2021) A force of 10 N acts on a mass of 2 kg. The acceleration produced is:
question.explanation: F = ma → a = F/m = 10 N / 2 kg = 5 m/s².

question.text: (SEBA 2021) The tendency of an object to resist change in its state of motion is called:
question.explanation: Inertia: property to resist change in state. Mass measures inertia. More mass → more inertia.

question.text: (CBSE 2020) Which has more inertia: a 5 kg iron ball or a 10 kg iron ball?
question.explanation: Inertia ∝ mass. Greater mass → greater inertia. 10 kg ball has twice inertia of 5 kg ball.

question.text: (SEBA 2020) When a bus starts suddenly, passengers fall backward due to:
question.explanation: Lower body moves with bus, upper body tends to remain at rest (inertia of rest) → fall backward.

question.text: (CBSE 2019) According to Newton's second law, F = ma. If force is doubled, acceleration:
question.explanation: F ∝ a (if m constant). Double force → double acceleration. a = F/m.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) The force required to stop a moving object depends on:
question.explanation: Force needed to change momentum. F = Δp/Δt = mΔv/Δt. Depends on mass and velocity change.

question.text: (CBSE 2018) A bullet of mass 20 g is fired with velocity 100 m/s. Its momentum is:
question.explanation: p = mv = 0.020 kg × 100 m/s = 2 kg·m/s. Remember to convert g to kg (20 g = 0.020 kg).

question.text: (SEBA 2018) When you jump from a boat to shore, the boat moves backward due to:
question.explanation: You push boat backward (action), boat pushes you forward (reaction). Equal and opposite forces.

question.text: Newton's second law gives the measure of:
question.explanation: F = ma defines force quantitatively. First law qualitatively. Third law: pair of forces.

question.text: A body of mass 1 kg has weight about:
question.explanation: Weight = mg = 1 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 9.8 N (approx 10 N for simplicity). g varies slightly with location.

question.text: Which of these experiences greater inertia?
question.explanation: Inertia depends on mass. Cricket ball has more mass than feather/paper → more inertia.

question.text: The momentum of an object changes from 10 kg·m/s to 20 kg·m/s in 2 seconds. Force applied is:
A person in moving bus throws a ball upward. The ball will:
question.explanation: Ball has same horizontal velocity as bus (inertia of motion). Moves with bus, falls back to hand.

question.text: When a carpet is beaten with a stick, dust comes out due to:
question.explanation: Carpet moves, dust tends to remain at rest (inertia) → separates from carpet.

question.text: A force of 5 N gives mass m₁ acceleration 10 m/s² and m₂ acceleration 20 m/s². Ratio m₁:m₂ is:
Rocket works on principle of:
question.explanation: Rocket: expels gas backward (action), gets forward thrust (reaction). Momentum conservation.

question.text: A body of mass 2 kg moving at 3 m/s collides with stationary 1 kg mass. After collision, they move together. Their common velocity is:
question.explanation: Momentum conservation: m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = (m₁+m₂)v → 2×3 + 1×0 = (2+1)v → 6 = 3v → v = 2 m/s.

question.text: The force experienced by a body of mass 0.5 kg falling freely is: (g=10 m/s²)
question.explanation: Force = weight = mg = 0.5 × 10 = 5 N downward.

question.text: Which law is called the law of conservation of momentum?
question.explanation: Momentum conservation derived from Newton's third law for isolated system (no external force).

question.text: A man pushing a wall gets tired because:
question.explanation: Third law: he pushes wall (action), wall pushes him back (reaction). He exerts force but no displacement → no work.

question.text: If the net force on a body is zero, it may:
question.option: Both be at rest or move with constant velocity
question.explanation: First law: if F_net = 0, body remains at rest or uniform motion (constant velocity, zero acceleration).

question.text: A force of 100 N acts on 50 kg mass at rest. Distance covered in 4 seconds is:
Inertia of direction is tendency to resist change in:
question.explanation: Types of inertia: 1) of rest, 2) of motion (speed), 3) of direction. Example: mud flying off rotating tire.

question.text: A 1000 kg car moving at 20 m/s stops in 5 seconds. Average braking force is:
question.explanation: F = mΔv/Δt = 1000×(0-20)/5 = -4000 N (magnitude 4000 N opposite to motion).

question.text: Which of these is NOT an example of third law?
question.explanation: Book on table: balanced forces (weight down, normal up) → first law. Action-reaction pairs act on different bodies.

question.text: The linear momentum of a body changes from 20 kg·m/s to 10 kg·m/s in 0.1 s. Force is:
question.explanation: F = Δp/Δt = (10-20)/0.1 = -10/0.1 = -100 N (opposite to motion).

question.text: A force produces acceleration a in mass m. Same force on mass 2m produces acceleration:
question.explanation: F constant, a ∝ 1/m. Double mass → half acceleration. a₂ = (m₁/m₂)a₁ = (m/2m)a = a/2.

question.text: When a horse pulls a cart, the force that makes horse move forward is exerted by:
question.explanation: Horse pushes ground backward (action), ground pushes horse forward (reaction). Friction enables this.

question.text: 1 kgf (kilogram-force) is equal to:
question.explanation: 1 kgf = weight of 1 kg mass = 1 × 9.8 = 9.8 N. Sometimes approximated to 10 N.

question.text: A body is moving with constant speed in circular path. The net force is:
question.explanation: Centripetal force required for circular motion, directed toward center. Changes direction, not speed.

question.text: If action and reaction are equal and opposite, why don't they cancel?
question.explanation: Action-reaction act on different objects, so don't cancel for individual objects. Net force on system may be zero.

question.text: A bullet of mass 10 g is fired with velocity 200 m/s from gun of mass 2 kg. Recoil velocity of gun is:
question.explanation: Conservation: m₁v₁ = m₂v₂ → 0.01×200 = 2×v → v = 2/2 = 1 m/s backward.

question.text: The rate of change of momentum is equal to:
question.explanation: Newton's second law: F = dp/dt. Force = rate of change of momentum.

question.text: A body of mass 5 kg moving at 4 m/s is acted by force 10 N for 2 s in direction of motion. Final velocity is:
